summary: This FBI Director's Morning Briefing summarizes news coverage from August 27, 2019, regarding the Epstein case. It covers defense attorneys questioning Epstein's death as suicide, alleged victims testifying in court and naming recruiters, and victims calling for accountability for Epstein's associates.

persons.name: Jeffrey E. Epstein
persons.role: Accused financier and alleged sex trafficker
persons.context: The Manhattan financier who died by apparent suicide while facing sex trafficking charges; his defense attorneys are questioning the circumstances of his death.

persons.name: Richard M. Berman
persons.context: Presiding judge in the Epstein case who allowed alleged victims to testify and was asked by defense attorneys to investigate Epstein's death.

persons.name: Reid H. Weingarten
persons.context: One of Epstein's attorneys who asked Judge Berman to conduct an independent inquiry into Epstein's death, citing evidence suggesting possible assault.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Named by some of Epstein's alleged victims in court testimony as a recruiter; she has denied wrongdoing and has not been charged at this time.

persons.name: Sarah Kellen
persons.context: Named by some of Epstein's alleged victims in court testimony as a recruiter; she has denied wrongdoing and has not been charged at this time.

persons.name: Virginia Guiffre
persons.context: Among the women who spoke out; she claimed Epstein ordered her to have sex with powerful friends including Prince Andrew and is now demanding answers from him.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Named by Virginia Guiffre as someone Epstein ordered her to have sex with; Prince Andrew has denied the allegations.

persons.name: Jennifer Araoz
persons.context: One of the women who testified in court, expressing anger that Epstein's suicide deprived her of facing her predator in court.

persons.name: Chauntae Davies
persons.context: One of the women who testified in court, vowing not to let Epstein 'win in death.'

persons.name: Mola Lenghi
persons.context: CBS reporter who covered the court proceedings and reported on victims naming Maxwell and Kellen.

persons.name: Tom Llamas
persons.context: ABC reporter who covered Virginia Guiffre's allegations involving Prince Andrew.

persons.name: Stephanie Gosk
persons.context: NBC reporter who covered the defense attorneys raising the theory that Epstein was strangled.

events.title: Court Hearing for Epstein Case Victims
events.description: U.S. District Judge Richard Berman allowed more than a dozen of Epstein's alleged victims to testify in a packed New York courtroom, despite Epstein's death. Victims described alleged rape and manipulation and called for accountability for Epstein's associates.

events.title: Defense Attorneys Question Epstein's Death
events.description: Epstein's defense attorneys, led by Reid Weingarten, asked Judge Berman to conduct an independent inquiry into Epstein's death, alleging evidence is 'far more consistent with assault' than suicide and raising the theory he was strangled.

events.title: Epstein's Apparent Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by apparent suicide earlier in August 2019 while in custody, facing sex trafficking charges. The New York City medical examiner concluded it was suicide, but defense attorneys and others have raised suspicions.

keyFacts: Epstein's defense attorneys publicly challenged the official suicide ruling, stating they had evidence 'far more consistent with assault' and asked a federal judge to independently investigate his death.
Multiple alleged victims of Jeffrey Epstein testified in court, with some specifically naming Ghislaine Maxwell and Sarah Kellen as recruiters in his alleged sex trafficking operation.
Virginia Guiffre, an accuser, escalated her allegations by demanding answers from Prince Andrew, whom she claims Epstein ordered her to have sex with.
The hearing occurred after federal prosecutors had begun winding down the criminal case due to Epstein's death, but the judge allowed victims to speak, providing a public forum for their testimony.
